Satellite Federated Edge Learning: Architecture Design and Convergence Analysis

Yuanming Shi, Senior Member, IEEE, Li Zeng, Graduate Student Member, IEEE, Jingyang Zhu, Graduate Student Member, IEEE, Yong Zhou, Senior Member, IEEE, Chunxiao Jiang, Senior Member, IEEE,
 and Khaled B. Letaief, Fellow, IEEE Yuanming Shi, Li Zeng, Jingyang Zhu, and Yong Zhou are with the School of Information Science and Technology, ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201210, China (e-mail: {{\{shiym, zengli, zhujy2, zhouyong}}\}@shanghaitech.edu.cn). Chunxiao Jiang is with the Tsinghua Space Center, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China. (e-mail: jchx@tsinghua.edu.cn). Khaled B. Letaief is with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Hong Kong (e-mail: eekhaled@ust.hk).
Abstract

The proliferation of low-earth-orbit (LEO) satellite networks leads to the generation of vast volumes of remote sensing data which is traditionally transferred to the ground server for centralized processing, raising privacy and bandwidth concerns. Federated edge learning (FEEL), as a distributed machine learning approach, has the potential to address these challenges by sharing only model parameters instead of raw data. Although promising, the dynamics of LEO networks, characterized by the high mobility of satellites and short ground-to-satellite link (GSL) duration, pose unique challenges for FEEL. Notably, frequent model transmission between the satellites and ground incurs prolonged waiting time and large transmission latency. This paper introduces a novel FEEL algorithm, named FedMega, tailored to LEO mega-constellation networks. By integrating inter-satellite links (ISL) for intra-orbit model aggregation, the proposed algorithm significantly reduces the usage of low data-rate and intermittent GSL. Our proposed method includes a ring all-reduce based intra-orbit aggregation mechanism, coupled with a network flow-based transmission scheme for global model aggregation, which enhances transmission efficiency. Theoretical convergence analysis is provided to characterize the algorithm performance. Extensive simulations show that our FedMega algorithm outperforms existing satellite FEEL algorithms, exhibiting an approximate 30% improvement in convergence rate.

Index Terms:
Satellite communication, federated edge learning, low-earth-orbit mega-constellation, inter-satellite link.

I Introduction

As the 5G communication technology has matured into its commercialization phase and witnessed widespread global deployments [1], both the academic and industrial communities have turned their attention towards the conceptualization and foundational groundwork for the impending 6G communication systems [2]. The seamless integration of artificial intelligence (AI) with communication networks, as well as the emergence of non-terrestrial networks, are widely considered as the most salient features of the upcoming 6G era [3, 4]. Thanks to the abundance of data, advancements in machine learning (ML) algorithms, and exponential growth in computing power, AI has shown unparalleled proficiency across diverse tasks, such as image analytics and natural language processing. Recent progresses on large language models, e.g., ChatGPT and Bard, have further unleashed the wave of foundation models including general large language models and diverse industry-specific models such as medical models and remote sensing models [5]. Meanwhile, low-earth-orbit (LEO) satellite mega-constellations have been in active deployment around the world, e.g., Starlink [6], Kuiper [7], as well as China’s recently announced LEO constellation project for integrated communication and remote sensing [8]. Modern LEO mega-constellations typically encompass hundreds to tens of thousands of satellites flying at altitudes ranging from 300300300 to 200020002000 km, with an objective to achieve ubiquitous coverage in space, air, ground and sea, and further provide an array of services from communication and remote sensing to navigation and computation [9].

In addition to communication capabilities, modern LEO satellites are often equipped with various payloads such as computation and remote sensing. Recently, there has been a rapid development in various satellite on-board computing hardwares, such as on-board CPU [10], GPU [11], and other emerging in-orbit computing chips, leading to consistent advancements in on-board computation capabilities. These progresses make the in-orbit edge computing a reality [12] and on-board ML a promising trend [13, 14]. Meanwhile, benefiting from the low altitude of LEO satellites and maturity of remote sensing techniques like Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) and multi-spectral sensing technologies, coupled with the explosive growth in the number of satellites, an immense volume of high-resolution remote sensing data is being incessantly collected at the satellite edge [15]. Behind these voluminous and diverse data lies significant potential for information extraction and utilization. ML techniques, as the most prominent data mining methods in the current AI era, have been extensively explored in remote sensing data processing and offer various applications ranging from land cover classification [16], cloud detection [17], and precipitation estimation [18], to oil spill detection [19], and wildfire detection [20], etc.

The traditional way of training ML models on such massive remote sensing data involves transmitting the raw data to ground stations (GS) and further processing these data in cloud computing centers [21]. However, with the dramatic increase in data volumes and the limited and expensive spectral resources between the satellites and the ground, this method incurs unbearable and increasing communication costs. In addition, the utilization of raw data involves severe data privacy issues, especially for high-resolution satellite images, the use of which is stringently regulated by relevant legislation [22, 23]. In light of the two challenges on communication bottlenecks and data privacy, employing the computing capabilities at the satellite edge for in-orbit ML model training is emerging as a major trend [13, 24]. More specifically, we propose to leverage the federated edge learning (FEEL) paradigm [25] for satellites to tackle the challenge of data mining on massive distributed satellite data. In FEEL, we aim to collaboratively train a global model with data from multiple edge devices without any raw data leaving their devices. Specifically, the edge devices first employ various optimization methods such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD) to train a local model. The edge devices then transmit the local model parameters to the parameter server (PS) which aggregates the received model parameters and broadcast them back to all the edge devices, creating a iterative model training process. In FEEL, only model parameters are shared instead of massive raw data. This not only mitigates substantial communication overheads but also addresses potential privacy concerns associated with raw data sharing, effectively tackling the aforementioned two challenges.

I-A Challenges and Related Works

I-A1 Challenges for On-Board FEEL

Although the deployment of FEEL in terrestrial networks has been extensively studied and the solutions are relatively mature [26, 27, 28], implementing FEEL in LEO mega-constellation networks presents unique challenges due to the high mobility of satellites, i.e., extremely short communication windows and sporadic satellite-ground connections [29]. One of the significant characteristics of FEEL is the frequent model exchange between edge devices and the PS. However, in LEO networks, the communication window between a satellite, acting as the edge device, and the GS is exceptionally short. Missing this window necessitates a prolonged waiting period before re-establishing the connection, during which the FEEL process has to be suspended. Consequently, the ground PS often has to wait an extended time to collect all local models from the satellites, resulting in high latency.

I-A2 Recent Studies for On-Board FEEL

Many existing studies focused on proposing scheduling schemes to address challenges posed by ground-to-satellite link (GSL). For instance, the authors in [30, 31, 32, 33] focused on designing asynchronous FEEL mechanisms to reduce waiting time for model aggregation. The authors in [34] optimally scheduled the transmission-receiving time of the model parameters between the satellites and the GS. However, this approach might result in stale model parameters at the PS, causing a certain performance loss. Leveraging the mature inter-satellite link (ISL) technology for reducing the waiting time during GSL interruptions is an another main research direction [35, 36, 37]. The authors in [35] first proposed to use the intra-orbit ISLs to assist the model downloading from satellites to the ground and thus save the waiting time. Furthermore, the authors in [36] designed a scheme to choose the better sink satellite which acts as the relay node between other satellites and the ground. Moreover, inter-orbit ISL was also considered for the model aggregation across different orbits [38, 39].

I-A3 Recent Studies for Decentralized FEEL

Different from the client-server architecture [40], decentralized (gossip) SGD that utilizes the device-to-device communications has been considered in decentralized FEEL. For instance, a general framework for decentralized SGD with dynamic topology is proposed in [41]. The authors in [39] focused on decentralized satellite FEEL without the coordination of a ground PS, which substitutes the aggregation function of the ground PS for model aggregation both within the same satellite orbit and between different satellite orbits via ISLs. In addition, the authors in [42] proposed to leverage both device-to-device and device-to-server communications to facilitate an hybrid architecture that combines the client-server and decentralized FEEL architectures to accelerate the model convergence.

I-A4 Limitations of Existing Studies

However, existing works on deploying FEEL in LEO satellite networks with ISLs have not addressed several critical issues. Primarily, the existing literature only focuses on systems with a single GS, while in real systems there are usually multiple GSs communicating with satellites. Utilizing multiple GSs simultaneously can efficiently accelerate the model transmission between space and ground. Moreover, given that multiple satellites can concurrently establish links with a single GS, there is an absence of a well-designed cooperative transmission scheme that allows satellites to collaboratively accomplish a transmission task in a short period of time. Furthermore, existing literature overlooks the unique characteristics inherent to both ISL and GSL when tailoring rapid FEEL algorithms. Notably, ISL offers a significantly enhanced energy efficiency and data rate compared to GSL. This oversight leads to overuse of GSL in existing FEEL algorithms, resulting in excessive energy consumption and latency. By astutely integrating these characteristics and custom-adjusting the usage frequency of various links in FEEL implementation, we can achieve improved performance with respect to the convergence speed of FEEL algorithms.

To this end, we consider the deployment of FEEL in LEO mega-constellation systems with multiple GSs and propose the FedMega algorithm through a synergistic integration of architecture design and transmission scheme design.

I-B Contributions

In this paper, we develop an efficient FEEL framework tailored for the LEO mega-constellation network. Leveraging the superior data rate and stability of intra-orbit ISL over GSL, we introduce multiple intra-orbit training rounds per global round to reduce the GSL usage. Utilizing the orbit’s ring topology, we propose an efficient communication scheme for intra-orbit aggregation based on the ring all-reduce algorithm. For rapid global model aggregation, we also propose an efficient model transmission mechanism based on the network flow algorithm, which further mitigates the delay. Furthermore, to characterize the convergence performance of the proposed algorithm, we theoretically analyze its convergence rate, taking into account non-convex loss functions and non-IID data distributions.

The major contributions are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose a novel and fast convergent FEEL algorithm tailored for the LEO network. This approach leverages the inherent stability and ultra-high transmission rates of intra-orbit ISL compared to GSL. Specifically, we increase the model aggregation frequency within each orbit, which solely relies on ISL, while reducing communication frequency between orbiting satellites and the ground PS, which relies on GSL. Within each global iteration, multiple intra-orbit cycles occur, wherein each satellite undergoes local training and subsequently attains the intra-orbit averaged model. At the end of each global iteration, a global aggregation transpires, where the ground PS retrieves models from space via GSL. This approach adeptly minimizes GSL dependence, thereby mitigating communication latency.

  2. 2.

    To quickly accomplish the intra-orbit model aggregation step, we leverage the ring topology within each orbit and the full-duplex capability of laser ISL and propose an efficient ring all-reduce-based intra-orbit model aggregation scheme. This scheme ensures that every satellite within an orbit can acquire the intra-orbit averaged model, with the execution time upper bounded by a constant irrespective of the number of satellites in the orbit.

  3. 3.

    To accelerate the global model aggregation step, we propose an efficient network flow-based model transmission scheme. This scheme can maximize the number of model parameters received per time slot by the ground PS. Since the total amount of model parameters to transmit is fixed, the latency is thereby minimized.

  4. 4.

    We provide a comprehensive convergence analysis of the proposed FedMega algorithm under non-convex settings and non-IID data distribution. We demonstrate that the proposed FedMega algorithm attains linear speedup in terms of the number of local updates, the number of LEO satellites, and the number of intra-orbit aggregations.

In realistic LEO network settings, extensive simulations on both synthetic datasets and real datasets are conducted. The results demonstrate that our proposed FedMega can achieve a better prediction accuracy and faster convergence rate than existing benchmarks, which verifies the superiority of the proposed FedMega algorithm.

I-C Organization and Notations

For the remainder, we begin by introducing the system model of satellite FEEL in Section II. Next, we present the proposed FedMega framework, which includes the algorithm workflow as well as the efficient model transmission scheme in Section III. Then, we analyze the convergence of the proposed algorithm in Section IV. Subsequently, we provide the simulation results in Section V. Lastly, we summarize the conclusions and the future research directions.

II System Model

In this section, we first introduce the mathematical model of FEEL over LEO satellites and then provide a detailed characterization of the satellite FEEL system.

II-A FEEL over LEO Mega-Constellation Network

We consider the deployment of FEEL in an LEO mega-constellation network, as shown in Fig. 1, wherein a ground PS coordinates satellites from M𝑀M circular orbits indexed by ℳ:={1,2,…,M}assignℳ12…𝑀\mathcal{M}:=\left\{1,2,\dots,M\right\} with the help of G𝐺G GSs indexed by 𝒢:={1,2,…,G}assign𝒢12…𝐺\mathcal{G}:=\left\{1,2,\dots,G\right\} to collaboratively train a global model. These GSs, dispersed across different geographic regions, primarily serve as relays between the ground PS and satellites. Specifically, each orbit m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M} comprises Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m} satellites denoted as 𝒦m:={𝖲m,1,𝖲m,2,…,𝖲m,Km}assignsubscript𝒦𝑚subscript𝖲𝑚1subscript𝖲𝑚2…subscript𝖲𝑚subscript𝐾𝑚\mathcal{K}_{m}:=\left\{\mathsf{S}_{m,1},\mathsf{S}_{m,2},\dots,\mathsf{S}_{m,K_{m}}\right\}. 𝒛⋆=arg⁡min𝒛∈ℝd⁡F​(𝒛):=∑m=1M∑k=1Kmwm,k​Fm,k​(𝒛),superscript𝒛⋆subscript𝒛superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝒛assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝑤𝑚𝑘subscript𝐹𝑚𝑘𝒛{\bm{z}}^{\star}=\arg\min_{{\bm{z}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F({\bm{z}}):=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sum_{k=1}^{K_{m}}w_{m,k}F_{m,k}({\bm{z}}), (2)

A common strategy for efficiently solving this problem is to employ distributed Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), wherein each satellite updates its local model via SGD and shares its local model with the PS [40], i.e., the ground PS periodically downloads the satellites’ local models, aggregates local models to update the global model, and then uploads the updated global model to all satellites to initiate the next round’s on-board training, as shown in Fig. 1. However, this approach can hardly be directly applied in LEO networks due to the unique challenges. In the following, we introduce the network model of modern LEO mega-constellations and identify these challenges.

II-B Network Model of LEO Mega-Constellations

In this subsection, we establish a network model for a LEO mega-constellation, with a focus on describing the network topology as well as the link characteristics. The entire network consists two sub-networks, i.e., the ground sub-network including the ground PS and GSs, and the space sub-network including all satellites. We start by introducing the nodes and connectivity inside each sub-network, followed by a description of the connectivity between two sub-networks.

II-B1 Ground Sub-Network

The ground sub-network consists of a central PS and G𝐺G GSs. The ground PS is the top control unit that is responsible for global model maintenance and coordinating the operations of all nodes. The G𝐺G GSs at different geographic locations serve for establishing connectivity between the ground PS and the orbiting satellites. High-speed ground dedicated lines (GDL) are deployed between the PS and each GS [21]. Note that due to the high construction costs of GSs and GDLs, the number of GSs, i.e., G𝐺G, is much smaller than the number of satellites in a mega-constellation, i.e., G≪∑m=1MKmmuch-less-than𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚G\ll\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m}. The ground sub-network exhibits a star topology as shown in Fig. 2(a).

II-B2 Space Sub-Network

The space sub-network is composed of all orbiting satellites, i.e., ∪m=1M𝒦msuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝒦𝑚\cup_{m=1}^{M}\mathcal{K}_{m}, as well as the ISL. Without loss of generality, we assume that each orbit m𝑚m is circular and the Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m} satellites are evenly spaced along the orbit. The satellite numbering scheme is as follows: we first arbitrarily choose a satellite and designate it as 𝖲m,1subscript𝖲𝑚1\mathsf{S}_{m,1}, then assign the remaining satellites in the ascending order according to their locations along the orbit in the clockwise direction, i.e., each satellite 𝖲m,k∈𝒦msubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘subscript𝒦𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,k}\in\mathcal{K}_{m} is located between 111-hop neighbors 𝖲m,(k−1)%​Kmsubscript𝖲𝑚percent𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,(k-1)\%K_{m}} and 𝖲m,(k+1)%​Kmsubscript𝖲𝑚percent𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,(k+1)\%K_{m}}. Since satellites within the same constellation system often have similar hardware configurations, we reasonably assume that the computation and communication hardwares on different satellites share equivalent performance [43]. Typically, the space sub-network exhibits the following features:

Laser-based link implementation and its characteristics

As laser has been broadly recognized as the primary implementation method for ISL [44] and the latest LEO projects, e.g., Telesat, Starlink and Kaskilo, have all started to deploy laser ISLs [45, 46, 47], it is reasonable and practical to incorporate the laser ISL into the system model. Specifically, we outline some of the key characteristics of laser ISL as follows.

  • •

    High data rate and low power consumption. Laser ISL, operating within the unlicensed spectrum, consistently attains data transmission rates up to 100 gigabits per second, surpassing traditional RF links in both speed and energy efficiency due to its highly focused beams [48].

  • •

    Full-duplex capability. Laser ISLs supports full-duplex communication [49], allowing simultaneous transmitting and receiving.

  • •

    Free of interference. The focused beam of light used in laser ISL ensures that signals would not be affected by electromagnetic interference or other signal interference.

We remark that the above features render laser ISL a particularly attractive option for the transmission of large-sized data.

Stable ring topology inside each orbit

In each orbit m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M}, each satellite 𝖲m,k∈𝒦msubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘subscript𝒦𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,k}\in\mathcal{K}_{m} maintains two laser ISLs to connect its immediately adjacent satellites, i.e., one laser ISL for connecting 𝖲m,(k+1)%​Kmsubscript𝖲𝑚percent𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,(k+1)\%K_{m}} and the other for 𝖲m,(k−1)%​Kmsubscript𝖲𝑚percent𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,(k-1)\%K_{m}}, thus each orbit can be viewed as a ring. In dense mega-constellations, the line-of-sight path between adjacent satellites generally is not obstructed by the Earth’s surface. Moreover, due to the fact that satellites in the same orbit are relatively stationary with respect to each other, the intra-orbit laser ISLs are permanently stable [44, 46].

In addition, inter-orbit laser ISLs are not considered in this work due to issues like severe Doppler shifts deteriorating link quality [50]. Overall, the space sub-network, as illustrated in Fig. 2(b), is modeled as a collection of stable rings. For notation ease, 𝖨𝖲𝖫m​(k1,k2)subscript𝖨𝖲𝖫𝑚subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2\mathsf{ISL}_{m}(k_{1},k_{2}) is used to represent the laser ISL between two satellites 𝖲m,k1∈𝒦msubscript𝖲𝑚subscript𝑘1subscript𝒦𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,k_{1}}\in\mathcal{K}_{m} and 𝖲m,k2=𝖲m,(k1±1)%​Kmsubscript𝖲𝑚subscript𝑘2subscript𝖲𝑚percentplus-or-minussubscript𝑘11subscript𝐾𝑚\mathsf{S}_{m,k_{2}}=\mathsf{S}_{m,(k_{1}\pm 1)\%K_{m}}.

II-B3 Ground-Space Connection

The connections between the ground and space sub-networks rely on the GSL. We use 𝖦𝖲𝖫gm​(k),g∈𝒢,m∈ℳ,k∈𝒦mformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝖦𝖲𝖫𝑔𝑚𝑘𝑔𝒢formulae-sequence𝑚ℳ𝑘subscript𝒦𝑚\mathsf{GSL}_{g}^{m}(k),g\in\mathcal{G},m\in\mathcal{M},k\in\mathcal{K}_{m} to denote the GSL between 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k} and GS g𝑔g. Typically, GSL exhibits the following features:

RF-based GSL

Unlike laser ISLs, GSLs are mainly based on radio frequency (RF) technology. Besides, to establish a link with GS g𝑔g, satellite 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k} must maintain a minimum elevation angle ϕesubscriptitalic-ϕe\phi_{\mathrm{e}}, i.e.,

∠​(𝒓𝖲m,k−𝒓g,𝒓g)≤90∘−ϕe,∠subscript𝒓subscript𝖲𝑚𝑘subscript𝒓𝑔subscript𝒓𝑔superscript90subscriptitalic-ϕe\angle\left({{\bm{r}}}_{\mathsf{S}_{m,k}}-{{\bm{r}}}_{g},{{\bm{r}}}_{g}\right)\leq 90^{\circ}-\phi_{\mathrm{e}}, (3)

where 𝒓𝖲m,ksubscript𝒓subscript𝖲𝑚𝑘{\bm{r}}_{\mathsf{S}_{m,k}} and 𝒓gsubscript𝒓𝑔{\bm{r}}_{g} denote the coordinate vectors of 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k} and GS g𝑔g in the geocentric coordinate system, respectively. This is mainly applied for preventing severe signal attenuation caused by thick atmosphere. In addition, GSL in LEO networks exhibits very different characteristics compared to the terrestrial links and laser ISL presented as follows:

  • •

    Low data rate and high power consumption. Due to a variety of factors such as limited bandwidth, strong interference, severe Doppler effect, significant atmospheric attenuation, and even unstable weather conditions, GSL typically offers a much lower data rate but significantly higher energy cost than laser ISL [51, 50].

  • •

    Short link duration. Due to the low altitude and high mobility of LEO satellites, the GSL establishment condition (3) can rarely be satisfied. Thus, each GSL’s duration would be extremely short. In modern LEO constellations, the duration of a GSL is only around 0.5∼5similar-to0.550.5\sim 5 minutes [52]. This induces a highly dynamic topology between the ground and space sub-networks, which complicates routing and link scheduling for data transmission [52].

Multi-point to multi-point communication

With the help of mature multi-beam and multiple access technologies, once the link establishment conditions are satisfied, a single satellite can communicate with multiple GSs at the same time, while a single GS can also serve multiple satellites simultaneously, as shown in Fig. 2(c).

Sporadic ground-space connections

Due to the short duration and limited number of GSs, the connectivity between the GSs and satellites tends to display sporadic characteristics [29, 31]. That is, at any given timestamp, only a small proportion or possibly none of the satellites are capable of establishing feasible GSLs.

In summary, the ground sub-network with a star topology and the space sub-network with a multi-ring topology both exhibit stable topological structures. However, the ground-space connection exhibits sporadic feature, highly dynamic topology, and low data rate. The whole system model is depicted in Fig. 3.

II-C Challenges for Efficient Satellite FEEL System Design

In this subsection, we discuss the challenges for efficient FEEL system design. FEEL, as a distributed learning paradigm, typically relies on efficient local model training and frequent model sharing. However, model sharing within integrated space-ground networks exhibits substantial differences compared to ground-only networks. To be specific, short-lived and low-speed GSLs pose two primary challenges:

  1. 1.

    Long waiting time for feasible GSLs: To perform FEEL training, the ground PS typically needs to aggregate local models from satellites as well as send the updated global model back to satellites, which requires feasible GSLs for model transmission between the space and the ground. However, given the sporadic nature of ground-space connectivity, such GSLs may not be instantly accessible. Hence, it would cause a long waiting time for feasible GSLs [31, 34, 32] in the global model aggregation and broadcasting phase.

  2. 2.

    High latency during GSL transmission: In the global model aggregation step, after waiting for a feasible GSL, model transmission between the space and the ground starts. However, the low data rate of GSLs may cause a high latency for the model transmission. Meanwhile, due to the short duration of GSL, the model transmission may not be able to be completed in one GSL connectivity session and have to experience another long waiting process during which no GSL is feasible. Moreover, both the size of the learning model on each satellite and the total number of satellites in a mega-constellation may be considerably large, resulting in a huge amount of model parameters to be downloaded. This further increases the transmission latency for local model downloading via GSL.

In view of the challenges delineated above, in the following, we shall propose the FedMega algorithm.

III Topology-Aware Efficient satellite FEEL Architecture

In this section, we first present general guidelines of architecture design based on the system features, followed by proposing the FedMega algorithm which exploits the characteristics of the network topology.

III-A Design Principles

As presented in Section II, efficiently deploying satellite FEEL faces two critical challenges, i.e., long waiting time for feasible GSLs and high GSL transmission latency. A well-designed algorithm should address these two challenges by mitigating the long waiting time and minimizing the transmission latency. In light of this, we shall propose two general principles for satellite FEEL system design:

  1. 1.

    Minimizing GSL utilization: Recognizing that any utilization of GSL might incur waiting time, the proposed FEEL framework should minimize the frequency of GSL utilization. This approach is intended to alleviate the challenge of excessive waiting time.

  2. 2.

    Reducing GSL transmission load: To minimize the latency incurred by transmitting models via GSL, the volume of data sent over each GSL should be reduced. This objective can be realized by distributing the total transmission workload across multiple GSLs and enabling collaboration among them.

In the following, we shall present the FedMega algorithm, which has been developed based on the above design guidelines.

III-B Proposed FedMega Framework

FedMega is specifically tailored to fit the unique network topology and link characteristics of the LEO network. The general workflow of FedMega is presented in Fig. 4. Specifically, in each global round, the algorithm procedures are divided into three phases: on-board local training, intra-orbit aggregation, and global aggregation and broadcasting, as elaborated below.

III-B1 On-Board Local Training

In this phase, each satellite 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k} undergoes local training by performing E𝐸E steps of mini-batch SGD on a randomly sampled subset of its local dataset, represented by ξm,kr,t,e⊆Dm,ksuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒subscript𝐷𝑚𝑘\xi_{m,k}^{r,t,e}\subseteq D_{m,k}. At each step e=0,1,…,E−1𝑒01…𝐸1e=0,1,\dots,E-1, the local model update is computed as follows:

𝒛m,kr,t,e+1=𝒛m,kr,t,e−ηr,t,e​∇Fm,kr,t,e​(𝒛m,kr,t,e).superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒1superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒superscript𝜂𝑟𝑡𝑒∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒{\bm{z}}_{m,k}^{r,t,e+1}={\bm{z}}_{m,k}^{r,t,e}-\eta^{r,t,e}\nabla F_{m,k}^{r,t,e}({\bm{z}}_{m,k}^{r,t,e}). (4)

Here, ηr,t,esuperscript𝜂𝑟𝑡𝑒\eta^{r,t,e} represents the stepsize, and ∇Fm,kr,t,e​(𝒛m,kr,t,e)∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒\nabla F_{m,k}^{r,t,e}({\bm{z}}_{m,k}^{r,t,e}) denotes the stochastic gradient of the local loss function Fm,k​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑚𝑘⋅F_{m,k}(\cdot) at point 𝒛m,kr,t,esuperscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒{\bm{z}}_{m,k}^{r,t,e} with respect to the mini-batch ξm,kr,t,esuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝑒\xi_{m,k}^{r,t,e}.

III-B2 Intra-Orbit Aggregation

After performing E𝐸E rounds of on-board local training, our objective is to attain a periodic averaged intra-orbit global model with the intention of enhancing the performance and generalization abilities of a global model. Specifically, each satellite should attain the intra-orbit model average 𝒛¯mr,t+1=∑k′=1Kmwm,k′​𝒛m,k′r,t,E∑k′=1Kmwm,k′superscriptsubscript¯𝒛𝑚𝑟𝑡1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘′1subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝑤𝑚superscript𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚superscript𝑘′𝑟𝑡𝐸superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘′1subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝑤𝑚superscript𝑘′\bar{\bm{z}}_{m}^{r,t+1}=\frac{\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{{K}_{m}}w_{m,k^{\prime}}{\bm{z}}_{m,k^{\prime}}^{r,t,E}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{{K}_{m}}w_{m,k^{\prime}}} as the new start point of local training.

However, in the LEO network, the frequent transmission of all local models to the ground PS for global model aggregation introduces significant waiting time and transmission latency due to the usage of GSLs. Nevertheless, as detailed in the system model in Section II, laser ISLs provide stable and rapid connections among satellites within the same orbit, resulting in a ring topology. This advantageous characteristic inspires us to explore the potential of utilizing laser ISLs for efficient intra-orbit aggregation within the orbit, consequently attaining a certain level of aggregation effectiveness. This intra-orbit aggregation leverages the stable, high-speed laser ISLs within the orbit, eliminating the significant transmission latency and conserving energy. Following several rounds of intra-orbit aggregation, a global aggregation is performed. This design significantly diminishes the waiting time for GSLs during the aggregation process and accelerates model training by reducing the utilization frequency of GSLs.

Moreover, in the FedMega algorithm, the ring topology of satellites in the same orbit is leveraged, utilizing the ring all-reduce method from high-performance computing [53] for model aggregation. The operations and principle of the ring all-reduce method are illustrated in Fig. 5, which depicts a half-duplex scenario for ease of understanding. The procedure of ring all-reduce aided intra-orbit aggregation is provided in Algorithm 1, where the full-duplex feature of laser ISL is utilized to double the aggregation speed compared to conventional ring all-reduced methods.

Specifically, without loss of generality, we assume that d𝑑d is divisible by 2​Km2subscript𝐾𝑚2K_{m}. Then, each satellite 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k} partitions its local model 𝒛m,kr,t,Esuperscriptsubscript𝒛𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑡𝐸\bm{z}_{m,k}^{r,t,E} into 2​Km2subscript𝐾𝑚2K_{m} chunks, i.e., 𝒃m,k+,[0],𝒃m,k−,[0],𝒃m,k+,[1],…,𝒃m,k−,[Km−1]superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑚𝑘delimited-[]0superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑚𝑘delimited-[]0superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑚𝑘delimited-[]1…superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑚𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝐾𝑚1\bm{b}_{m,k}^{+,[0]},\bm{b}_{m,k}^{-,[0]},\bm{b}_{m,k}^{+,[1]},\dots,\bm{b}_{m,k}^{-,[K_{m}-1]}, where

{𝒃m,k+,[u]=wm,k∑k′=1Kmwm,k′𝒛m,kr,t,E[u​dKm+1:(u+1/2)​dKm]𝒃m,k−,[u]=wm,k∑k′=1Kmwm,k′𝒛m,kr,t,E[(u+1/2)​dKm+1:(u+1)​dKm],\left\{\begin{aligned} &\bm{b}_{m,k}^{+,[u]}=\frac{w_{m,k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K_{m}}w_{m,k^{\prime}}}\bm{z}_{m,k}^{r,t,E}\left[\frac{ud}{K_{m}}+1:\frac{(u+1/2)d}{K_{m}}\right]\\ &\bm{b}_{m,k}^{-,[u]}=\frac{w_{m,k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K_{m}}w_{m,k^{\prime}}}\bm{z}_{m,k}^{r,t,E}\left[\frac{(u+1/2)d}{K_{m}}+1:\frac{(u+1)d}{K_{m}}\right],\end{aligned}\right. (5)

and u=0,1,…,Km−1𝑢01…subscript𝐾𝑚1u=0,1,\dots,K_{m}-1. Then, there are totally 2​Km−22subscript𝐾𝑚22K_{m}-2 iterations. In each iteration i𝑖i, each satellite only needs to transmit one chunk per laser ISL, and hence only needs 12​Km12subscript𝐾𝑚\frac{1}{2K_{m}} time compared to transmit the whole model. The total time cost 2​Km−22​Km2subscript𝐾𝑚22subscript𝐾𝑚\frac{2K_{m}-2}{2K_{m}} is upper bounded by a constant (e.g., 1) irrelevant to Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m}, which implies that the intra-orbit model aggregation step is scalable with respect to the constellation scale. Consequently, orbits with different numbers of satellites are expected to incur almost the same time cost for intra-orbit aggregation, which enhances the synchronization of the system. As a result, each satellite finally acquires the averaged model from all satellites within its orbit, allowing them to proceed to the next intra-orbit round’s local training or global aggregation. Ideally, our algorithm achieves optimal time complexity when data rates of the ISL are uniform. However, when the inter-satellite link rates vary between different satellites and change over time in real systems, the overall performance is limited by the slowest one.

III-B3 Global Aggregation and Broadcasting

After multiple intra-orbit rounds, the algorithm advances to the global aggregation phase, which involves aggregating all satellites’ local models via GSLs. The updated global model is then disseminated to all satellites to initiate a new global round. As previously mentioned, the long transmission latency presents a core challenge during this phase. To this end, a two-step strategy is employed in FedMega, i.e.,

  1. 1.

    First, given that all satellites within a given orbit share an identical intra-orbit model upon completing the ring all-reduce-assisted intra-orbit aggregation, the ground PS merely needs to communicate with any single satellite in that orbit to obtain the corresponding intra-orbit aggregation outcome. This method avoids the need to retrieve each satellite’s local model individually, thereby considerably reducing the data download volume.

  2. 2.

    Secondly, as multiple GSLs may be feasible at the same time, a network flow based distributed transmission scheme is proposed. This method involves partitioning the model downloading task into sub-tasks, where multiple feasible GSLs from LEO satellites in one orbit collaboratively execute the model downloading, as illustrated in Fig. 6. Consequently, the load on each GSL is alleviated, leading to a substantial reduction in the overall transmission latency.

Specifically, at the onset of global aggregation, time is partitioned into discrete time slots. Within each individual time slot, the feasibility and transmission rate of all GSLs are invariant. Consequently, the ground PS is able to acquire a graph 𝒢𝒢\mathscr{G}, which represents the present network connectivity, as illustrated in Fig. 7. In this representation, each satellite 𝖲m,k∈𝒦subscript𝖲𝑚𝑘𝒦\mathsf{S}_{m,k}\in\mathcal{K} corresponds to vertex 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k}, each GS g𝑔g is represented by vertex 𝖦𝖲gsubscript𝖦𝖲𝑔\mathsf{GS}_{g}, the ground PS is denoted by vertex 𝖽𝖽\mathsf{d}, and each edge (𝗏1,𝗏2)subscript𝗏1subscript𝗏2(\mathsf{v}_{1},\mathsf{v}_{2}) in the right portion signifies a feasible link between 𝗏1subscript𝗏1\mathsf{v}_{1} and 𝗏2subscript𝗏2\mathsf{v}_{2} within the current time slot. The capacity c𝗏1,𝗏2subscript𝑐subscript𝗏1subscript𝗏2c_{\mathsf{v}_{1},\mathsf{v}_{2}} of this edge is equivalent to the maximum fraction of a model that the link can transmit in the current time slot, expressed as c𝗏1,𝗏2=r𝗏1,𝗏2​Δ​τθsubscript𝑐subscript𝗏1subscript𝗏2subscript𝑟subscript𝗏1subscript𝗏2Δ𝜏𝜃c_{\mathsf{v}_{1},\mathsf{v}_{2}}=\frac{r_{\mathsf{v}_{1},\mathsf{v}_{2}}\Delta\tau}{\theta}, where r𝗏1,𝗏2subscript𝑟subscript𝗏1subscript𝗏2r_{\mathsf{v}_{1},\mathsf{v}_{2}} denotes the data rate of the link in the current time slot, Δ​τΔ𝜏\Delta\tau represents the duration of the time slot, and θ𝜃\theta indicates the model size.

To expedite the downloading process, we maximize the data volume received by ground PS in each time slot, which is formulated as a network flow problem. The construction of this network flow problem can be described as follows, with reference to Fig. 7. A vertex 𝗌𝗌\mathsf{s} represents a virtual source node, while each orbit m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M} is denoted by a vertex 𝖮msubscript𝖮𝑚\mathsf{O}_{m}. Every vertex 𝖮msubscript𝖮𝑚\mathsf{O}_{m} is connected to all vertices corresponding to satellites in orbit m𝑚m. This signifies that each satellite can only transmit the aggregated intra-orbit model of the orbit to which it belongs. All edges between satellite vertices and orbit vertices have a constant capacity of one, implying that the proportion of the intra-orbit model allocated to each satellite to transmit can not exceed 100%. Additionally, the source vertex 𝗌𝗌\mathsf{s} is connected to all orbit vertices, with the edge capacity c𝗌,𝖮msubscript𝑐𝗌subscript𝖮𝑚c_{\mathsf{s},\mathsf{O}_{m}} representing the fraction of orbit m𝑚m’s intra-orbit model that remains untransmitted as of the current time slot. Hence, at the beginning of each time slot, the ground PS can schedule the transmission task of each GSL by solving this network flow problem, until all orbits’ intra-orbit models have been transmitted. The distributed and adaptive transmission scheme is summarized in Algorithm 2. After aggregation of the intra-orbit models from all orbits, we obtain an updated global model. The ground PS transmits this updated global model back to all satellites with a similar distributed and adaptive uploading scheme.

In summary, the proposed satellite FEEL framework includes on-board local training, intra-orbit aggregation, and global aggregation and broadcasting, as summarized in Algorithm 3.

III-C Advantages of FedMega Framework

The proposed FedMega aligns with the core design guidelines, i.e., GSL utilization minimization and transmission load reduction, thereby speeding up the FEEL training process. The implementation of multiple intra-orbit rounds can reduce the gradient estimation variance within one orbit within very short time. This effectively mitigates the frequency of GSL utilization, consequently diminishing the waiting time required for feasible GSLs. In terms of intra-orbit model aggregation, the ring all-reduce-based scheme significantly reduces the communication overhead, i.e., time and energy cost. Furthermore, the adoption of a distributed and adaptive model transmission scheme alleviates the transmission load burden on each GSL, thereby accelerating the downloading process.

IV Convergence Analysis for FedMega

In this section, we present the convergence analysis of the FedMega algorithm. To ensure that our analysis is relevant to practical scenarios (e.g., deep neural networks), we focus on the situations where non-convex loss functions and non-IID data are present. In order to make convergence analysis tractable, we make the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

The objective function F𝐹F is lower bounded by a scalar Finfsuperscript𝐹infimumF^{\inf}, i.e., F​(𝐱)≥Finf>−∞𝐹𝐱superscript𝐹infimumF(\bm{x})\geq F^{\inf}>-\infty.

Assumption 2 (L𝐿L-Smoothness).

The loss function of each satellite 𝖲m,ksubscript𝖲𝑚𝑘\mathsf{S}_{m,k}, each orbit m𝑚m, and all orbits, i.e., Fm,k​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑚𝑘⋅F_{m,k}(\cdot), Fm​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑚⋅F_{m}(\cdot), and F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) are all L𝐿L-smooth. For all 𝐱𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲𝐲\bm{y}, we have

‖∇Fm,k​(𝒙)−∇Fm,k​(𝒚)‖2≤L​‖𝒙−𝒚‖,subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑚𝑘𝒙∇subscript𝐹𝑚𝑘𝒚2𝐿norm𝒙𝒚\|\nabla F_{m,k}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{m,k}(\bm{y})\|_{2}\leq L\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|,

and

F​(𝒚)≤F​(𝒙)+⟨∇F​(𝒙),𝒚−𝒙⟩+L2​‖𝒚−𝒙‖22.𝐹𝒚𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒙𝒚𝒙𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒚𝒙22F(\bm{y})\leq F(\bm{x})+\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{x}),\bm{y-x}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\|\bm{y-x}\right\|_{2}^{2}.
Assumption 3 (Unbiased Gradient and Bounded Variance).

Each satellite can query an unbiased stochastic gradient with bounded variance, i.e.,

Assumptions 1-3 are common in stochastic optimization [54]. Assumption 4 is adopted to characterize the gradient dissimilarity between each satellite’s loss function and the corresponding orbit’s loss function [42]. Assumption 5, known as the bounded gradient dissimilarity [55] measures the non-IID degree of data on different devices.

Based on Theorem 1, we obtain the following key observations. The first term of the upper bound demonstrates that the optimality gap depends on the initial point. The second term is caused by bounded variance, multiple orbits, and multiple intra-orbit aggregations. The third term reflects the impact of multiple local updates. The fourth term shows the coupling of multiple local updates, multiple intra-orbit aggregations, and the non-IID data distribution. The last term is caused by the gradient variance.

Remark 1.

By setting T=1𝑇1T=1, FedMega reduces to the conventional FedAvg with multiple local updates [56]. Furthermore, by setting E=1,T=1formulae-sequence𝐸1𝑇1E=1,T=1, FedMega recovers the results of the fully synchronized SGD as in [54]. By setting E=1,T=τformulae-sequence𝐸1𝑇𝜏E=1,T=\tau, FedMega also reduces to the fully connected case (i.e., the mixing matrix of D2D communication links is an all-ones matrix) of the HL-SGD [42].

By designing the learning rate, we can derive the following corollary with E,T,R≫1much-greater-than𝐸𝑇𝑅1E,T,R\gg 1.

Corollary 1 (Error Bound of FedMega under Non-convexity).

When the learning rate is a constant satisfying η=1L​KE​T​R𝜂1𝐿𝐾𝐸𝑇𝑅\eta=\frac{1}{L}\sqrt{\frac{K}{ETR}}, the minimal gradient norm of the global objective function of FedMega is bounded as follows

mint∈[T],r∈[R]⁡𝔼​[‖∇F​(𝒛¯r,t)‖22]≤𝒪​(1+σ2K​E​T​R)subscriptformulae-sequence𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝑟delimited-[]𝑅𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript¯𝒛𝑟𝑡22𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝐾𝐸𝑇𝑅\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T],r\in[R]}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla F(\bar{\bm{z}}^{r,t})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1+\sigma^{2}}{\sqrt{KETR}}\right)
+\displaystyle+ 𝒪​(M−1R​KE​T​R)+𝒪​(K​[σ2+δ¯2+E​(T2+1)]T​R).𝒪𝑀1𝑅𝐾𝐸𝑇𝑅𝒪𝐾delimited-[]superscript𝜎2superscript¯𝛿2𝐸superscript𝑇21𝑇𝑅\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{M-1}{R}\sqrt{\frac{K}{ETR}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{K[\sigma^{2}+\bar{\delta}^{2}+E(T^{2}+1)]}{TR}\right). (9)

The right hand side of the inequality is dominated by 𝒪​(1+σ2K​E​T​R)𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝐾𝐸𝑇𝑅\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1+\sigma^{2}}{\sqrt{KETR}}\right).

To measure the convergence performance with respect to communication efficiency and the parameters that determining the architecture design of FedMega (i.e., E,T𝐸𝑇E,T), we have the following remark for discussion.

Remark 2.

FedMega achieves a linear speed-up in terms of the number of LEO satellites (i.e., K𝐾K), the number of local updates (i.e., E𝐸E), and the number of intra-orbit aggregations (i.e., T𝑇T). We say that solution 𝐳tsuperscript𝐳𝑡\bm{z}^{t} is an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary point if ‖∇f​(𝐳t)‖22≤ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝐳𝑡22italic-ϵ\left\|\nabla f(\bm{z}^{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon. According to Corollary 1, the learning rate η=1L​KE​T​R𝜂1𝐿𝐾𝐸𝑇𝑅\eta=\frac{1}{L}\sqrt{\frac{K}{ETR}} decreases with the number of local updates and the number of intra-orbit aggregations. To achieve an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary solution, the FedMega algorithm takes E​T​R=(1+σ2)2K​ϵ2𝐸𝑇𝑅superscript1superscript𝜎22𝐾superscriptitalic-ϵ2ETR=\frac{(1+\sigma^{2})^{2}}{K\epsilon^{2}} total iterations. If we increase the product of the number of local updates and intra-orbit aggregations, then we can obtain a solution with higher accuracy and smaller learning rate occupying the same number of communication rounds (i.e., R𝑅R). In addition, if E​T​R𝐸𝑇𝑅ETR is fixed, we can increase the product E​T𝐸𝑇ET to reach the same level of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary solution, which results in reducing the number of communication rounds to enhance the communication efficiency. However, due to data heterogeneity, E​T𝐸𝑇ET can not be infinite large, and the optimal choice of E​T𝐸𝑇ET is 𝒪​(RK)𝒪𝑅𝐾\mathcal{O}(\frac{R}{K}).

To conclude, we minimize the frequency of GSL utilization by implementing multiple rounds of on-board local training and intra-orbit aggregations, which accelerates the convergence of FedMega as analyzed in Remark 2. To compare the convergence rate of FedMega with existing studies, we have the following remark.

Remark 3.

As a matter of fact, FedMega achieves a hierarchical distributed SGD convergence rate as in [57, 58], which is T𝑇\sqrt{T} times faster than FedAvg and its implementation on LEO satellites (i.e., FedISL) [35] in terms of total iterations. FedMega is also E𝐸\sqrt{E} times faster than the upper bound of the HL-SGD [42]. Besides, to support the three-layer client-edge-cloud hierarchical FEEL on the ground, more intra-orbit aggregations cause frequently device-to-server communications, which is definitely not communication-efficient. However, a hierarchical distributed SGD convergence rate can be realized on satellite FEEL over the LEO mega-constellations with only two-layer orbit-ground architecture by fully exploiting the parallel computing property of ring all-reduce for intra-orbit aggregations. Thus FedMega is both communication-efficient and structure-efficient.

V Simulations

We evaluate the performance of the proposed satellite FEEL algorithm, i.e., FedMega, for different learning tasks and in different network settings in this section.

V-A Experiment Setup

V-A1 LEO Mega-Constellation Network Configurations

To verify the performance of the satellite FEEL algorithms, we consider two different network settings, as visualized in Fig. 8. The first one is a 300/6/130061300/6/1 Walker Delta constellation system and the second one is a 80/4/1804180/4/1 Walker Delta constellation system. In the 300/6/130061300/6/1 Walker Delta setting, there are M=6𝑀6M=6 orbits and K0=50subscript𝐾050K_{0}=50 satellites evenly distributed in each orbit. In 80/4/1804180/4/1 Walker Delta setting, there are M=4𝑀4M=4 orbits and K0=20subscript𝐾020K_{0}=20 satellites evenly distributed in each orbit.

For both systems, all the satellites are at a 500500500 km altitude and there are G=6𝐺6G=6 GSs located at Beijing (39.928939.928939.9289°N, 116.388116.388116.388°E), Berlin (52.516752.516752.5167°N, 13.413.413.4°E), Cape Town (−33.916733.9167-33.9167°N, 18.416718.416718.4167°E), Rio De Janeiro (−22.922.9-22.9°N, −43.233343.2333-43.2333°E), Syndey (−33.883333.8833-33.8833°N, 151.217151.217151.217°E), Toronto (43.666743.666743.6667°N, −79.416779.4167-79.4167°E), respectively.

V-A2 Learning Tasks

The following three learning tasks are used to evaluate the performance of the FEEL algorithms.

  • •

    Synthetic data classification[59]. For this task, we train a deep neural network (DNN) on Synthetic⁡(0.5,0.5)Synthetic0.50.5\operatorname{Synthetic}(0.5,0.5) dataset generated in [59, Section 5.1], which contains 10 labels of data. The DNN is a two-layer feedforward neural network with 60 input neurons, 20 hidden neurons, and 10 output neurons. The local data generated by each satellite is assumed to be non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) in each orbit. In this experiment, each satellite contains Unif⁡(50,450)Unif50450\operatorname{Unif}(50,450) data samples. The batch-size is set to be 25. The learning rate is set to be 0.01. The number of communication round R𝑅R, the number of intra-orbit rounds T𝑇T, and the number of local update E𝐸E are set to be 600, 10, and 5, respectively.

  • •

    Land cover classification on EuroSAT [60]. In this task, we train a ResNet-18 neural network model on the Sentinel-2 satellite RGB images to classify the land cover and land use. In fact, satellites are capable of retrieving land cover labels for remote sensing images by matching the geographical location information of captured images with the geographic information database on the ground. This enables the acquisition of labels for remote sensing images to be used for training purposes. Specifically, the dataset contains 27,000 images with 10 classes of land cover illustrated in Fig. 9. The local data of each satellite is assumed to be IID sized Unif⁡(300,375)Unif300375\operatorname{Unif}(300,375). The batch-size is set to be 161616. The learning rate is set to be 1×10−41superscript1041\times 10^{-4}. The number of intra-orbit rounds T𝑇T, and the number of local update E𝐸E are set to be 555, and 202020, respectively.

  • •

    Nighttime light intensity prediction. The aim of this task is to train a neural network model on daytime satellite images to predict the nighttime light intensity level of the corresponding area [61]. As for the dataset details, a total of 42,000 locations were randomly selected within the territories of Ethiopia, Malawi, and Nigeria. Corresponding daytime satellite images were collected from Google Earth as the training data, nighttime light intensity data is acquired from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) as the labels, where the light intensity categorized into 888 classes, as shown in Fig. 10. A neural network model based on the ResNet-18 architecture is then trained on this data set. The local data in each satellite is assumed to be non-IID in each orbit, i.e., each satellite contains data with at most 222 kinds of labels. Each satellite contains Unif⁡(600,750)Unif600750\operatorname{Unif}(600,750). Other configurations are the same as the second task.

We run the experiments on PyTorch version 2.0.0, CUDA version 11.7, and python version 3.9.

V-A3 Baselines

We consider the following algorithms for comparison:

  • •

    FedMega: The proposed algorithm.

  • •

    HL-SGD: The distributed algorithm exploiting both GSLs and ISLs. For intra-orbit aggregations, only the adjacent satellites exchange their local models [42].

  • •

    FedISL: Vanilla FedAvg executed by LEO satellites [35] in one orbit.

V-A4 Delay Computation of Satellite FEEL

We now present the delay computation for all baselines. For FedMega, in each communication round, we denote the delay of a single on-board local update, ring all-reduce based intra-orbit aggregation, and distributed downloading as tcompsubscript𝑡compt_{\text{comp}}, trarsubscript𝑡rart_{\text{rar}}, and tdownsubscript𝑡downt_{\text{down}}, respectively. Besides, the time occupied for waiting a feasible GSL and global model broadcasting is denoted as twaitsubscript𝑡waitt_{\text{wait}} and tbcsubscript𝑡bct_{\text{bc}}. In this case, the total delay of communication round r𝑟r can be written as

TFedMegar=2​tdownr+tbcr+T​(E​tcompr+trarr)+twaitr,superscriptsubscript𝑇FedMega𝑟2subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟downsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟bc𝑇𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟compsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟rarsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟wait\displaystyle T_{\textsc{FedMega}}^{r}=2t^{r}_{\text{down}}+t^{r}_{\text{bc}}+T(Et^{r}_{\text{comp}}+t^{r}_{\text{rar}})+t^{r}_{\text{wait}}, (10)

where we assume that the downlink GSL and the uplink one are dual process. To be specific, let I𝐼I be the model size of the model parameter (0.5GB for Synthetic data classification and 3GB for nighttime intensity prediction), γgslsubscript𝛾gsl\gamma_{\text{gsl}} be the average data rate of the GSL, and γislsubscript𝛾isl\gamma_{\text{isl}} be the average data rate of the laser ISL, we have

tdown=Iγgsl,tbc=Iγisl,trar=2​K−22​K​Iγisl+(2​K−2)​tsum,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡down𝐼subscript𝛾gslformulae-sequencesubscript𝑡bc𝐼subscript𝛾islsubscript𝑡rar2𝐾22𝐾𝐼subscript𝛾isl2𝐾2subscript𝑡sum\displaystyle t_{\text{down}}=\frac{I}{\gamma_{\text{gsl}}},t_{\text{bc}}=\frac{I}{\gamma_{\text{isl}}},t_{\text{rar}}=\frac{2K-2}{2K}\frac{I}{\gamma_{\text{isl}}}+(2K-2)t_{\text{sum}}, (11)

where tsumsubscript𝑡sumt_{\text{sum}} is the time for performing a summation in Algorithm 1. Assume that, γisl=10subscript𝛾isl10\gamma_{\text{isl}}=10 GB/s [46], tcompr=2subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟comp2t^{r}_{\text{comp}}=2 s for Synthetic data classification task and 555 s for nighttime intensity prediction task, and tsum=0.01subscript𝑡sum0.01t_{\text{sum}}=0.01 s. The satellite-ground communication is modeled as a digital communication process over a complex Gaussian channel, where the link rate γgslsubscript𝛾gsl\gamma_{\text{gsl}} is computed based on the Shannon formula, i.e., γgsl=B​log2⁡(1+H​Pt​Gt​GsB​N0),subscript𝛾gsl𝐵subscript21𝐻subscript𝑃𝑡subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝐺𝑠𝐵subscript𝑁0\gamma_{\text{gsl}}=B\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{HP_{t}G_{t}G_{s}}{BN_{0}}\right), where H=(c04​π​fc​d)2𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑐04𝜋subscript𝑓𝑐𝑑2H=\left(\frac{c_{0}}{4\pi f_{c}d}\right)^{2} is the free space loss, d𝑑d is the distance and fc=32subscript𝑓𝑐32f_{c}=32 GHzGHz\mathrm{GHz} is the carrier frequency. Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t} is the transmission power set to be 404040 dBmdBm\mathrm{dBm}, Gt=15subscript𝐺𝑡15G_{t}=15 dBidBi\mathrm{dBi} and Gs=30subscript𝐺𝑠30G_{s}=30 dBidBi\mathrm{dBi} are the transmitter and receiver antenna gains. B𝐵B is the bandwidth set to be 62.562.562.5 MHzMHz\mathrm{MHz}. The elevation angle is set to be π/4𝜋4\pi/4. The access time is the time required for establishing a connection between the satellite and the ground, set to be 10 seconds.

For comparison, we also assume that the delay tdownsubscript𝑡downt_{\text{down}}, tbcsubscript𝑡bct_{\text{bc}}, tcompsubscript𝑡compt_{\text{comp}}, and twaitsubscript𝑡waitt_{\text{wait}} are the same for HL-SGD and FedISL. The differences lie in the number of local updates and the intra-orbit aggregations. The total delay of communication round r𝑟r for HL-SGD and FedISL can be written as

where thybridrsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟hybridt^{r}_{\text{hybrid}} and tislrsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟islt^{r}_{\text{isl}} are the delay of intra-orbit model exchange proposed in [42] and model transmission in the orbit [35], respectively.

V-B Performance Evaluation

We perform the simulation of synthetic data classification task in the 300/6/130061300/6/1 Walker Delta constellation and the nighttime light intensity prediction task in the 80/4/1804180/4/1 Walker Delta constellation, respectively.

V-B1 Learning Performance versus Communication Rounds

The training loss and the test accuracy versus communication rounds of Synthetic data classification are shown in Fig. 11. It can be observed that with ISL equipped, both FedMega and HL-SGD drastically outperform FedAvg without ISLs. As analyzed in Remark 3, FedMega converges faster and achieves higher accuracy than HL-SGD in the presence of intra-orbit heterogeneous data. As illustrated in Fig. 12, in the land cover classification task with IID data splitting, FedMega shares the same learning performance with HL-SGD. This means HL-SGD is not robust to non-IID data and FedMega outperforms HL-SGD in the non-IID settings. Let’s consider the land cover classification task for an example, the highest accuracy after 150 communication rounds for FedMega, HL-SGD, and FedISL is 86.91%percent86.9186.91\%, 86.85%percent86.8586.85\%, and 67.70%percent67.7067.70\%, respectively. In all, the convergence speed-up of FedMega is consistent with our analysis in Remark 3.

V-B2 Learning Performance versus System Delay

Based on the delay analysis in Section V-A, the training loss and the test accuracy versus system delay of Synthetic data classification and nighttime intensity prediction are illustrated in Figs. 13 and 14. From Figs. 13 and 14, we can conclude that FedMega has the smallest system delay to reach a targeted learning performance. For instance, in the task of Synthetic data classification, FedMega demonstrates a significant delay reduction to reach test accuracy of 60%percent6060\%, up to 66.9%percent66.966.9\% and 85.1%percent85.185.1\% compared with HL-SGD and FedAvg, respectively. The delay reduction can be observed in the task of nighttime intensity prediction as well.

V-B3 Trade-off Analysis

In Remark 2, we state that the product E​T𝐸𝑇ET cannot be infinite large. Besides, we can also observe from (10) that a large E​T𝐸𝑇ET will result in a large system delay of FedMega. Therefore, there is a trade-off between frequent intra-orbit aggregations and the system latency for achieving a certain convergence accuracy. To verify this, we first fix the number of local updates, i.e., E=5𝐸5E=5, and then derive the system delay to reach test accuracy of 65%,70%percent65percent7065\%,70\%, and 75%percent7575\% under different choices of T𝑇T in the Synthetic data classification task, which is shown in Fig. 15.

From Fig. 15, we can summarize that the number of intra-orbit aggregations T𝑇T can be neither too smaller, e.g., T=1𝑇1T=1, nor too large, e.g., T=100𝑇100T=100. When T=30𝑇30T=30, FedMega has the smallest system delay to arrive at different levels of learning performance, which is definitely a proper design of T𝑇T.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we developed a fast-converging and communication-efficient satellite FEEL framework for LEO networks. Recognizing that the extensive use of GSL significantly hinders the convergence speed of satellite FEEL, we leveraged the high data rate of laser ISL along with the stable ring topology within each orbit. This approach introduces an intra-orbit model aggregation step, which substantially reduces GSL dependency and, consequently, reduces latency. To further accelerate the intra-orbit model aggregation, we employed a ring all-reduce-based transmission scheme, ensuring execution within a constant and short time irrelevant to the number of satellites. Additionally, we devised a network flow-based transmission scheme to further minimize the latency of the global model aggregation step. Comprehensive convergence analysis under non-convex settings and non-IID data distribution characterized the superior convergence performance of our proposed algorithm. Simulation results confirmed its superior performance compared to existing benchmarks.

Lemma 3.

Finally, by taking averaging for (A-B) from t=0𝑡0t=0 to T−1𝑇1T-1 and r=0𝑟0r=0 to R−1𝑅1R-1, we have the final results presented in the theorem.
